results.title: The Edge of the barrens
results.creator_credit: Dalton Muir, Hugh O'Connor, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A distinguished film study of the tundra of Canada’s sub-Arctic. It stretches from the polar sea to the southern treeline and supports, despite the permafrost, a surprising variety of life. Here you see the ungainly musk-ox, survivor of the Ice Age, and herds of caribou following the migrant trails; also birds and flowers, smaller animals, and insects. (Awards: Venice; Buenos Aires; Yorkton)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dalton Muir, Hugh O’Connor, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Edgar Allan Poe
results.creator_credit: Stuart O'Brien and Arthur G. Evans
results.brief_description: One of the first American writers of international importance, Poe became a widely read master of the short story, yet his life seemed a fabric of despair, failure, frustration and poverty. This film presents a sympathetic account of Poe’s life and work narrated by Lorne Greene. To conclude there is a reading of Poe’s famous poem, ANNABEL LEE

results.title: Eclipse '73
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Dassonville and Service du film de Research Scientifique
results.brief_description: A report on the solar eclipse of June 30, 1973 seen from the ground and from a plane. The 1973 eclipse was monitored in Africa, south of the Sahara. Deals with the considerable means employed by the international scientific community while showing the mechanics of an eclipse and its value for basic research. At Atar in the heart of the Mauritanian desert together with other Soviet, Japanese, Dutch and Italian scientists, the French mission brought in more than 20 tons of equipment, and used the most advanced technological means. The use of a supersonic Concorde 001, especially equipped by aerospace for this flight enabled them for the first time to monitor an eclipse for 74 minutes.

results.title: Echoes in Freestone
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale, Ray Barnes and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Using sounds from the past, over pictures of the present, the film glimpses a man’s life in pioneering days. Set in the historic town of Richmond, Tasmania, the film shows some of the classic colonial Georgian houses and churches, many of which date from the early days.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John M. Bale, Ray Barnes and Tasfilm Productions

results.title: The Echinoderms
results.creator_credit: Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Intertidal Life of the North American Pacific Coast”.
A few species of the phylum Echinodermata found in the rich environment of the North American Pacific coast are shows. Four of the five classes are found in the inter-tidal region: Asteroidea, sea-stars; Ophiuroidea, brittle stars; Holothuriodea, sea cucumbers; and Echinoidea, sea-urchins. Uses micro-photogpraphy.

results.title: Easy does it
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Anthony Gibb, Tasfilm Productions and Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1967 film is a light-hearted look at the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back strain and injury. The film shows footage of factory and manual labourers handling various heavy loads, including using equipment to aid safe lifting. This footage is interspersed with examples of everyday strain such as women hanging out the washing and lifting a baby from a pram; and moments of slapstick comedy as a man struggles to carry his bride over the threshold of their house and a man lifts a keg of beer at a barbeque.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
